articles.title: Teachers are the ‘guardians of our future’, says UN deputy chief
articles.summary: In every corner of the world, educators are making choices that echo across generations – influencing everything from the preservation of forests to the writing of poetry, the building of bridges to the holding of peaceful elections.
articles.content:
Their work, said UN Deputy Secretary-General Amina Mohammed, is “the beating heart of education, the cornerstone of sustainable development, and the guardians of our future.”

Speaking Thursday at the opening of the UNESCO World Summit on Teachers in Santiago, Chile, Ms. Mohammed called for urgent global action to address the deepening teacher crisis.

“Let us honour their influence with the policies and the respect that teachers need, and future generations deserve,” she urged, laying out a five-point plan to support educators and strengthen education systems worldwide.

A crisis with global consequences

The deputy UN chief warned that the world is facing a “deepening teacher crisis” that threatens progress across the Sustainable Development Goals.

“We are failing our teachers,” she said, pointing to a global shortfall of 44 million educators needed to meet universal education targets by 2030.

Tweet URL

She described the crisis as “a slow-burning emergency” that is undermining learning outcomes, widening inequalities, and weakening the social fabric of communities. “We must respond to those truths,” she said.

No single actor can fix this alone

UNESCO Director-General Audrey Azoulay also addressed the Summit, emphasizing the complexity of the challenge. “No single actor will be able to bridge the gaps we see, and that is what brings us together here in Santiago,” she said.

Ms. Azoulay highlighted the multiple causes behind the crisis: low and often delayed salaries, an aging teacher workforce, surging school enrolments without matching resources, and persistent gender inequalities – especially in STEM fields. Tackling these issues, she said, requires level heads and “clear thinking.”

The numbers are stark

To meet global education goals by 2030, the world must recruit 44 million teachers – more than double the population of Chile. Yet, instead of progress, gains are being reversed.

“Too many young teachers are leaving within their first years,” Ms. Mohammed said, citing low pay, heavy workloads, and lack of professional development. “Ultimately, we are asking the impossible of teachers: to build the future without the tools, trust and conditions they need.”

Financing the future

The cost of recruiting the teachers needed by 2030 is estimated at $120 billion annually. But education financing is falling short.

“More than 40 per cent of the world’s population lives in countries where governments spend more on debt interest payments than on education or health,” she warned.

Aid to education is projected to drop by 25 per cent between 2023 and 2027, with a 12 per cent fall already recorded last year.

© ECLAC Deputy Secretary General Amina Mohammed delivers remarks to the World Summit on Teachers in Santiago, Chile.

Five areas for urgent action

Ms. Mohammed laid out a five-point plan to tackle the global teacher crisis:

Elevate the profession: Implement the High-Level Panel’s recommendations — fair pay, stable contracts, safe workplaces, manageable class sizes, investment in upskilling, and clear career pathways. Finance education: Make education a top budget priority. Expand domestic funding, pursue debt relief, and consider a Global Fund for Teachers in Emergencies. Advance gender equality: Recognize and elevate women’s leadership in a profession dominated by women but often lacking female decision-makers. Support digital transformation: Train teachers to lead inclusive digital learning, especially as AI reshapes the job market. Equip classrooms and prioritize human agency. Protect teachers in crisis zones: From Gaza to Sudan and Ukraine, educators are risking their lives. “We owe them more than admiration – we owe them protection, resources, and unwavering support.”

From Summit to action

Ms. Mohammed urged leaders to turn the summit’s outcomes into concrete commitments ahead of the World Social Summit in Doha this November.

She proposed:

National teacher compacts with time-bound targets on recruitment, retention, and pay.

A financing track that links aid and debt swaps to teacher investments.

A teacher-led digital pact to set standards for AI and ed-tech, with funded training.

“Quality education is the foundation of everything we hope to achieve with the Sustainable Development Goals,” she concluded. “Without teachers, none of it is possible.”

articles.personality_title: UN calls for urgent global action to support teachers and secure education's future
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Around the world, teachers play a crucial role in shaping our future by educating children and helping communities grow. However, there is a serious shortage of teachers, which is making it harder to provide good education everywhere.

**What happened** – At the UNESCO World Summit on Teachers in Santiago, Chile, UN Deputy Secretary-General Amina Mohammed spoke about this growing teacher crisis. She said the world needs 44 million more teachers by 2030 to meet education goals. She shared a five-point plan to improve teachers’ work conditions, pay, and training, and called for more funding and protection, especially in crisis areas.

**Impact** – This crisis affects many parts of life, from learning to social equality. If there aren’t enough teachers, fewer children get a good education, which can make it harder for countries to develop and solve problems like poverty or climate change. The UN’s plan aims to fix this by making teaching a respected and well-supported profession worldwide.

**What's next step** – Leaders around the world will work to turn the summit’s ideas into real actions. They plan to set clear goals for hiring and keeping teachers, find new ways to pay for education, and help teachers use new technology like artificial intelligence in classrooms.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The UN is urging countries to act now to support teachers with better pay, training, and protection to ensure every child can receive a quality education by 2030.
articles.personality_title_fr: L’ONU appelle à une action mondiale urgente pour soutenir les enseignants et sécuriser l’avenir de l’éducation

**Contexte** – Partout dans le monde, les enseignants jouent un rôle essentiel en formant les enfants et en aidant les communautés à se développer. Cependant, il y a une grave pénurie d’enseignants, ce qui rend difficile l’accès à une bonne éducation partout.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Lors du Sommet mondial de l’UNESCO sur les enseignants à Santiago, au Chili, la vice-secrétaire générale de l’ONU, Amina Mohammed, a parlé de cette crise croissante des enseignants. Elle a déclaré que le monde a besoin de 44 millions d’enseignants supplémentaires d’ici 2030 pour atteindre les objectifs éducatifs. Elle a présenté un plan en cinq points pour améliorer les conditions de travail, les salaires et la formation des enseignants, et a appelé à plus de financement et de protection, notamment dans les zones de crise.

**Impact** – Cette crise affecte de nombreux aspects de la vie, de l’apprentissage à l’égalité sociale. S’il n’y a pas assez d’enseignants, moins d’enfants reçoivent une bonne éducation, ce qui peut compliquer le développement des pays et la résolution de problèmes comme la pauvreté ou le changement climatique. Le plan de l’ONU vise à résoudre ce problème en faisant de l’enseignement une profession respectée et bien soutenue dans le monde entier.

**Prochaine étape** – Les dirigeants du monde entier vont travailler pour transformer les idées du sommet en actions concrètes. articles.title: What Brazil’s digital fight means for free expression in the Global South
articles.summary: Brazil’s push to regulate Big Tech and protect digital rights is reshaping global debates and provoking backlash from powerful actors opposed to its rights-based, democratic model of internet governance.
articles.content:
By Sahasranshu Dash and Ana Tereza Duarte Lima de Barros

On July 30, 2025, U.S. President Donald Trump announced a 50 percent tariff on Brazilian exports, justifying this measure not by currency manipulation or unfair trade practices, but as a response to what he described as politically motivated persecution against former Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro. Trump specifically cited alleged human rights abuses and the censorship coercion of U.S. tech platforms, actions he attributed directly to rulings from Brazil's Supreme Court Justice Alexandre de Moraes.

For many digital rights advocates in Brazil, the tariff isn’t just an economic blow. It marks an escalation of pressure from one of the world’s most powerful countries against a rising Global South democracy that has dared to chart its own course on digital governance. Brazil’s effort to regulate Big Tech — long resisted by Silicon Valley and populist actors alike — is finally attracting global attention. And resistance.

A democratic vision of the digital sphere

While Brazil’s model might not be perfect, it’s one of the boldest in the Global South. The Marco Civil da Internet, the Brazilian ‘‘bill of rights for the internet,’’ signed by former president Dilma Rousseff in 2014, laid a foundational legal framework for net neutrality, user rights, and content moderation transparency. Four years later, the General Personal Data Protection Law (LGPD) built on that foundation to establish a strong personal data protection regime, partly inspired by the European Union’s General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR).

Yet what sets Brazil apart isn’t just its legislation, but the way courts and regulators have stepped in to enforce it in real-world scenarios. In March 2022, in an order by Moraes, the Supreme Federal Court (STF) temporarily blocked Telegram across the country after it repeatedly failed to comply with judicial orders aimed at curbing disinformation related to extremism and political violence. In August 2024, Moraes ordered the suspension of X (formerly Twitter) for refusing to remove harmful content, particularly posts targeting election officials and LGBTQ+ activists, reinforcing the court’s commitment to protecting democratic institutions and vulnerable communities.

Meanwhile, Brazil’s National Data Protection Authority (ANPD) has emerged as a key regulatory actor in digital governance. In July 2024, it suspended Meta’s privacy policy for AI systems that relied on users’ personal data, citing violations of constitutional rights. Crucially, the ANPD’s decision demanded greater transparency from companies developing AI, emphasizing the need for clear public disclosures on data usage, legal bases, and opt-out mechanisms for data subjects. Meta subsequently complied with these requirements by implementing a compliance plan that introduced clearer privacy notices, facilitated opt-out options, and restricted the use of data from minors, which led the ANPD to suspend its preventive measure.

Through these combined judicial and regulatory actions, Brazil has asserted a model of digital sovereignty rooted in constitutional accountability and rights-based enforcement.

These measures are not just administrative or bureaucratic moves; they represent a broader effort to reclaim the internet as a space for democratic discourse and user protection, pushing back against disinformation and online abuse. As Reporters Without Borders states in its recommendations for Brazil's digital future:

Platforms must highlight reliable news sources so people can access quality information. Platforms should be transparent about how their algorithms work, how they moderate content, and how they deal with government requests.

Civil society behind the push

This regulatory momentum hasn’t emerged from the government alone. Brazilian civil society organizations, journalists, and academic institutions have been central to shaping the country’s digital path. Groups such as InternetLab, Intervozes, and the Institute for Technology and Society (ITS Rio) have pushed for laws that protect vulnerable users, increase platform transparency, and resist surveillance.

Brazil’s so-called “Fake News Bill,” formally introduced in May 2020 and passed by the Senate, has remained under negotiation and revision ever since at the Deputies’ Chamber in the National Congress. It proposes a platform accountability framework requiring identification of inauthentic behavior, detection of coordinated manipulation, and enhanced visibility for verified information, specifically designed to avoid preemptive censorship.

While imperfect, the bill — drafted mid-2020 and still evolving — demonstrates a serious intent to safeguard civic space and demand accountability from dominant tech firms that shape public discourse.

The backlash — and its foreign backers

Unsurprisingly, Brazil’s rights-based and constitutionally grounded model of digital governance has not only attracted criticism but also triggered direct retaliation. In July 2025, the United States imposed sanctions on Supreme Court justice Alexandre de Moraes under the Global Magnitsky Act — a U.S. federal law that imposes sanctions such as US entry bans and asset freezes for people accused of human rights violations and corruption — accusing him of “an oppressive campaign of censorship” and “arbitrary detentions that violate human rights,” as reported by Reuters.

These sanctions followed sustained pressure from a transnational coalition of populist politicians, far-right influencers, and U.S.-based media outlets, who have targeted Moraes for his role in regulating digital platforms, investigating Bolsonaro’s alleged coup attempt, and dismantling disinformation networks. For defenders of Brazil’s regulatory framework, the move reflects not a defense of free expression, but an aggressive geopolitical rejection of a democratic country’s sovereign effort to govern the digital sphere.

Figures close to U.S. Vice President J.D. Vance and billionaire Peter Thiel have amplified accusations that Brazil’s courts are “anti-speech” or “authoritarian,” often through platforms and influencers aligned with their political and financial networks.

One prominent example is Rumble, a video platform backed by investors connected to both men, which was suspended in Brazil in February 2025 after repeatedly defying moderation orders from the Supreme Court.

Yet the double standards are glaring. While some U.S. voices decry supposed censorship in Brazil, American immigration authorities deny visas to foreign nationals based on the political content of their social media posts.

Why Brazil matters now

Brazil is more than a large democracy — it’s a test case for how digital sovereignty can be used to protect, not restrict, rights in the Global South. With over 180 million internet users and an increasingly connected population, what happens there could influence policy far beyond its borders.

Already, countries like Mexico, South Africa, Kenya, and Tunisia are drawing lessons from Brazil’s approach to regulating platforms, combating hate speech, and protecting user rights. Even amid rising opposition, Brazil is advancing new legislation to ban mass biometric surveillance without judicial oversight, increase penalties for data misuse, and guarantee human recourse in automated decisions.

These reforms aren’t just technocratic; they’re part of a broader effort to rebuild civic trust after years of far-right rule, institutional erosion, and digital manipulation.

That effort seems to be gaining traction: President Lula’s approval ratings have now overtaken his disapproval ratings for the first time in nine months, and Brazil’s Supreme Court — praised by democrats and civil society observers for its role in holding Bolsonaro and extremist networks accountable — is seen as a defender of democracy.

The stakes for digital rights in the Global South

Brazil’s digital fight is not just about local governance. It’s about whether countries in the Global South can govern their online spaces on their own terms, or whether they’ll be punished for diverging from a deregulated, U.S.-centric internet. The tariffs are economic on paper, but they’re political in spirit. They send a clear message: regulate tech platforms too boldly, and you may face backlash from those invested in the status quo.

For advocates of digital rights, Brazil’s experience offers both a warning and a roadmap. It shows how difficult, messy, and politicized this work can become — but also how crucial it is. The challenge now is to ensure that the space for civic agency, pluralism, and rights-based governance doesn’t shrink under pressure.

Because if Brazil succeeds, it won’t just be defending its democracy. It will be opening space for others to do the same.

Sahasranshu Dash is a research partner at the South Asia Institute of Research and Development in Kathmandu, Nepal. His work focuses on technology, state power, and political subjectivity in the Global South.

Ana Tereza Duarte Lima de Barros is a political scientist and PhD candidate in Political Science at the Federal University of Pernambuco (UFPE, Brazil). Her research centers on state capacity, political institutions, and government responses to the COVID-19 pandemic. She is a member of the Red de Politólogas and was a visiting doctoral researcher at the German Institute for Global and Area Studies (GIGA).

This has broad significance for the Global South and digital sovereignty worldwide, with concrete legal frameworks and enforcement actions that protect free expression, combat disinformation, and safeguard vulnerable communities. Despite facing backlash and geopolitical pressure, Brazil's model offers a hopeful roadmap for other countries seeking digital rights and democratic accountability.
articles.personality_title: Brazil leads a new path for digital rights and internet fairness
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Brazil has been working on laws and rules to make the internet safer and fairer for its people. These rules focus on protecting users’ rights, stopping harmful content, and making big tech companies more responsible. This approach is different from many other countries, especially powerful ones like the United States.

**What happened** – In recent years, Brazil’s courts and government agencies have taken strong actions against social media platforms like Telegram, X (formerly Twitter), and Meta for not following rules about harmful content and user privacy. Brazil’s data protection authority even made Meta change its privacy policies to better protect users, especially children. However, these efforts have led to pushback, including economic tariffs and sanctions from the U.S. against Brazilian officials, accusing them of censorship.

**Impact** – Brazil’s actions are important because they show how a large democracy in the Global South can protect digital rights and hold powerful tech companies accountable. This model is inspiring other countries like Mexico, South Africa, and Kenya to consider similar rules. Brazil’s efforts help defend free expression and protect vulnerable groups online, even when facing pressure from stronger countries and companies.

**What's next step** – Brazil plans to introduce new laws to ban mass biometric surveillance without court approval and increase penalties for misuse of personal data. The country will continue working to balance internet freedom with safety and privacy. Other nations watching Brazil may follow its example, which could change how the internet is governed worldwide.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Brazil is showing that it’s possible for countries to create fair and protective internet rules that respect users’ rights, even when facing challenges from powerful global actors.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le Brésil ouvre la voie à de nouveaux droits numériques et à une internet plus juste
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Le Brésil travaille sur des lois et des règles pour rendre Internet plus sûr et plus juste pour sa population. Ces règles visent à protéger les droits des utilisateurs, à stopper les contenus nuisibles et à rendre les grandes entreprises technologiques plus responsables. Cette approche diffère de celle de nombreux autres pays, notamment des plus puissants comme les États-Unis.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Ces dernières années, les tribunaux et agences gouvernementales brésiliens ont pris des mesures fortes contre des plateformes comme Telegram, X (anciennement Twitter) et Meta, qui ne respectaient pas les règles sur les contenus nuisibles et la vie privée des utilisateurs. L’autorité brésilienne de protection des données a même contraint Meta à modifier ses politiques de confidentialité pour mieux protéger les utilisateurs, surtout les enfants. Ces efforts ont cependant entraîné des réactions, notamment des sanctions économiques des États-Unis contre des responsables brésiliens, les accusant de censure.

**Impact** – Les actions du Brésil sont importantes car elles montrent comment une grande démocratie du Sud peut protéger les droits numériques et tenir les grandes entreprises technologiques responsables. Ce modèle inspire d’autres pays comme le Mexique, l’Afrique du Sud et le Kenya à envisager des règles similaires. Les efforts du Brésil contribuent à défendre la liberté d’expression et à protéger les groupes vulnérables en ligne, même face à la pression de pays et d’entreprises puissants.

**Prochaine étape** – Le Brésil prévoit d’adopter de nouvelles lois pour interdire la surveillance biométrique de masse sans approbation judiciaire et renforcer les sanctions en cas d’abus des données personnelles. Le pays continuera à chercher un équilibre entre liberté, sécurité et vie privée sur Internet. D’autres nations qui observent le Brésil pourraient suivre son exemple, ce qui pourrait transformer la gouvernance mondiale d’Internet.

**En une phrase** – Le Brésil montre qu’il est possible pour les pays de créer des règles justes et protectrices pour Internet, respectant les droits des utilisateurs, même face à des défis venant d’acteurs mondiaux puissants.
articles.personality_title_es: Brasil marca un nuevo camino para los derechos digitales y un internet más justo
articles.personality_presentation_es:

Estas reglas protegen los derechos de los usuarios, detienen el contenido dañino y hacen que las grandes empresas tecnológicas sean más responsables. Este enfoque es diferente al de muchos otros países, especialmente potencias como Estados Unidos.

**Qué pasó** – En los últimos años, los tribunales y agencias del gobierno brasileño han tomado medidas fuertes contra plataformas como Telegram, X (antes Twitter) y Meta por no cumplir con las reglas sobre contenido dañino y privacidad. La autoridad de protección de datos de Brasil obligó a Meta a cambiar sus políticas para proteger mejor a los usuarios, especialmente a los niños. Sin embargo, estas acciones provocaron reacciones, incluyendo sanciones económicas y castigos de EE.UU. contra funcionarios brasileños por supuesta censura.

**Impacto** – Las acciones de Brasil son importantes porque muestran cómo una gran democracia del Sur Global puede proteger los derechos digitales y hacer responsables a las grandes empresas tecnológicas. **Próximo paso** – Brasil planea introducir nuevas leyes para prohibir la vigilancia biométrica masiva sin aprobación judicial y aumentar las sanciones por mal uso de datos personales. Continuará buscando un equilibrio entre libertad, seguridad y privacidad en internet. Otros países que observan a Brasil podrían seguir su ejemplo, cambiando la forma en que se gobierna internet en todo el mundo.

**Resumen en una frase** – Brasil demuestra que es posible que los países creen reglas justas y protectoras para internet que respeten los derechos de los usuarios, aun cuando enfrentan desafíos de actores globales poderosos.

articles.title: Despite Taliban ban, over 90 per cent of Afghans support girls’ right to learn
articles.summary: Despite the ongoing ban on girls’ secondary education, more than 90 per cent of Afghan adults support girls’ right to be in class, according to a new alert from the UN’s gender equality agency, UN Women.
articles.content:
Four years after the Taliban takeover in August 2021, the scale and severity of the women’s rights crisis continues to intensify. Afghanistan is the only country in the world where girls are prohibited to attend secondary school.

Yet, in a nationwide door-to-door survey of over 2,000 Afghans, more than nine in 10 supported girls’ right to learn.

Tweet URL

“It is clear: Despite the existing bans, the Afghan people want their daughters to exercise their right to education,” said Sofia Calltorp, UN Women’s Chief of Humanitarian Action, at a press conference in Geneva on Friday.

'Education is the difference'

A protracted humanitarian crisis continues in Afghanistan coupled with systemic and institutionalised restrictions on women and girls’ rights.

Ms. Calltorp insisted that it is more important than ever to continue investing in Afghan women’s community organizations, which offer healthcare, mental health support and a chance to connect.

“In a country where half the population lives in poverty, education is the difference between despair and possibility,” she said, voicing their yearning to be back in a school environment.

“This is almost always the first thing girls tell us – they are desperate to learn and just want the chance to gain an education,” said UN Women’s Special Representative in Afghanistan, Susan Ferguson.

A year after the introduction of a stricter so-called morality law codified a sweeping set of restrictions, the new alert highlights the deepening normalisation of the women’s rights crisis.

NGO work ban

The Taliban’s ban on women working for NGOs – announced nearly three years ago – continues to have a devastating impact, said UN Women.

More than half of NGOs in Afghanistan report that it has affected their ability to reach women and girls with vital services.

A UN Women survey conducted in July and August found that 97 per cent of Afghan women said it had negatively impacted them.
articles.source: UN News - Global perspective Human stories
articles.reasoning: The article highlights a strong, widespread public support (over 90%) in Afghanistan for girls' right to education despite the Taliban's ban, reflecting a hopeful and inspiring societal stance on human rights and gender equality. It provides detailed survey data and emphasizes the significance of education as a transformative factor, showing meaningful resistance and aspiration for positive change in a challenging context.
articles.personality_title: More than 90% of Afghans support girls’ right to education despite Taliban ban
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Since the Taliban took control of Afghanistan in 2021, girls have been banned from attending secondary school. This makes Afghanistan the only country in the world with such a strict rule against girls’ education.

**What happened** – A survey of over 2,000 Afghan adults found that more than 90 percent support girls going to school, even though the ban is still in place. UN Women, the United Nations agency for gender equality, shared these results and highlighted the strong desire among Afghan families for their daughters to learn.

**Impact** – This shows that most people in Afghanistan want girls to have the same chance to study as boys. Education is seen as a way to improve lives and offer hope in a country facing poverty and many challenges. Despite laws and restrictions, families and girls themselves are eager for schooling.

**What’s next step** – UN Women and other groups plan to keep supporting Afghan women’s organizations that provide education and health services. They hope these efforts will help girls continue learning and eventually change the rules so all children can go to school safely.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Even with strict bans, most Afghans strongly believe girls should have the right to education and are working to make it happen.
articles.personality_title_fr: Plus de 90 % des Afghans soutiennent le droit des filles à l’éducation malgré l’interdiction des talibans
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Depuis la prise de pouvoir des talibans en Afghanistan en 2021, les filles sont interdites de fréquenter l’école secondaire. Cela fait de l’Afghanistan le seul pays au monde à appliquer une telle interdiction.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Une enquête auprès de plus de 2 000 adultes afghans a révélé que plus de 90 % soutiennent le droit des filles à aller à l’école, malgré l’interdiction toujours en vigueur. ONU Femmes, l’agence des Nations Unies pour l’égalité des genres, a partagé ces résultats, soulignant le fort désir des familles afghanes que leurs filles apprennent.

**Impact** – Cela montre que la plupart des gens en Afghanistan veulent que les filles aient la même chance d’étudier que les garçons. L’éducation est perçue comme un moyen d’améliorer la vie et d’offrir de l’espoir dans un pays confronté à la pauvreté et à de nombreux défis. Malgré les lois et restrictions, les familles et les filles elles-mêmes aspirent à l’école.

**Prochaine étape** – ONU Femmes et d’autres groupes prévoient de continuer à soutenir les organisations féminines afghanes qui offrent des services d’éducation et de santé. Ils espèrent que ces efforts permettront aux filles de poursuivre leur apprentissage et, à terme, de changer les règles pour que tous les enfants puissent aller à l’école en toute sécurité.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Même avec des interdictions strictes, la plupart des Afghans croient fermement que les filles doivent avoir le droit à l’éducation et travaillent pour y parvenir.
articles.personality_title_es: Más del 90 % de los afganos apoyan el derecho de las niñas a la educación a pesar de la prohibición talibán
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Desde que los talibanes tomaron el control de Afganistán en 2021, las niñas tienen prohibido asistir a la escuela secundaria. Esto convierte a Afganistán en el único país del mundo con esta estricta regla contra la educación de las niñas.

**Qué pasó** – Una encuesta a más de 2,000 adultos afganos encontró que más del 90 por ciento apoyan que las niñas vayan a la escuela, aunque la prohibición siga vigente. ONU Mujeres, la agencia de las Naciones Unidas para la igualdad de género, compartió estos resultados y destacó el fuerte deseo de las familias afganas de que sus hijas aprendan.

**Impacto** – Esto muestra que la mayoría de las personas en Afganistán quieren que las niñas tengan las mismas oportunidades de estudiar que los niños. La educación es vista como una forma de mejorar la vida y ofrecer esperanza en un país con pobreza y muchos desafíos. A pesar de las leyes y restricciones, las familias y las propias niñas desean asistir a la escuela.

**Próximo paso** – ONU Mujeres y otros grupos planean seguir apoyando a las organizaciones de mujeres afganas que ofrecen servicios educativos y de salud. Esperan que estos esfuerzos ayuden a las niñas a continuar aprendiendo y, eventualmente, a cambiar las reglas para que todos los niños puedan ir a la escuela de forma segura.

**Resumen en una frase** – Aunque existen prohibiciones estrictas, la mayoría de los afganos creen firmemente que las niñas deben tener derecho a la educación y están trabajando para lograrlo.

articles.title: Gonzato: Confronting the past requires concrete actions from Albanian institutions
articles.summary: Since 2017, the European Union has supported Albania in identifying individuals who went missing during the communist regime. Together with ICMP, the Authority of Files, and civil society, the EU has worked to strengthen coordination and raise public awareness.
articles.content:
Since 2017, the European Union has supported Albania in identifying individuals who went missing during the communist regime. Together with ICMP, the Authority of Files, and civil society, the EU has worked to strengthen coordination and raise public awareness.

On the International Day of Missing Persons, the scientific symposium “The Border of Hope and Death 1944-1991 – Shkodra Confronting the Past” was held at the “Luigj Gurakuqi” University in Shkodër, organized by the Authority of Files.

The Ambassador of the European Union, Silvio Gonzato, participated in this symposium, which was held in memory of the thousands of Albanian lives lost in the struggle for freedom by crossing the border and those who disappeared under the brutal communist regime.

Since 2017, the European Union has supported Albania in identifying the persons who went missing during the communist regime. Together with ICMP, the Authority of Files, and civil society, the EU has worked to strengthen coordination and raise public awareness.

“This day reminds us of many lost lives, as well as the families that still seek the truth and justice. For Albania, confronting the legacy of killings at the border and disappearances during the communist regime is a matter of dignity, justice, and building trust between citizens and institutions,” said Gonzato.

“Confronting the past requires political will, a functional legal framework, and, above all, concrete actions from the relevant Albanian institutions to ensure the rule of law. We urgently need the Council of Ministers to approve a coordinating mechanism among the relevant actors to enable the search and exhumation of persons killed during the communist regime,” he added.

“Confronting the past is a collective responsibility, where everyone has a role to play,” said the EU ambassador, Silvio Gonzato, in his speech.

This symposium was also attended by the Chairwoman of the Assembly, Elisa Spiropali, who delivered a welcoming speech.

This event was attended by former political prisoners from the communist regime and their family members and representatives, researchers, representatives of local governance, religious communities, and civil society. (August 29)

articles.personality_title: EU and Albania join forces to identify missing persons from communist era

**What happened** – On August 29, a scientific symposium called “The Border of Hope and Death 1944-1991 – Shkodra Confronting the Past” was held at Luigj Gurakuqi University in Shkodër. The event was organized by the Authority of Files and attended by the EU Ambassador Silvio Gonzato, Albanian officials, former political prisoners, and civil society members. They discussed the importance of identifying people who went missing during the communist era and called for stronger cooperation among Albanian institutions.

**Impact** – This work helps families learn the truth about their loved ones and supports justice by addressing past abuses. The EU’s involvement has improved coordination between government bodies and raised public awareness, which is essential for rebuilding trust between citizens and institutions in Albania.

**What’s next step** – Ambassador Gonzato urged the Albanian government to approve a plan that would organize the search and recovery of those killed during the regime. Concrete steps like this are needed to make sure the efforts continue and that missing persons are found and honored.

articles.personality_title_es: La UE y Albania unen fuerzas para identificar a los desaparecidos de la era comunista
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Entre 1944 y 1991, muchas personas en Albania desaparecieron o murieron al intentar escapar del régimen comunista. Desde 2017, la Unión Europea (UE) ha ayudado a Albania a encontrar a estas personas desaparecidas y a dar a conocer sus historias.

**Qué pasó** – El 29 de agosto se realizó un simposio científico llamado “La frontera entre la esperanza y la muerte 1944-1991 – Shkodër enfrentando el pasado” en la Universidad Luigj Gurakuqi de Shkodër. El evento fue organizado por la Autoridad de Archivos y contó con la presencia del embajador de la UE, Silvio Gonzato, funcionarios albaneses, ex presos políticos y miembros de la sociedad civil. Hablaron sobre la importancia de identificar a las personas desaparecidas durante la era comunista y pidieron una mejor cooperación entre las instituciones albanesas.

**Impacto** – Este trabajo ayuda a las familias a conocer la verdad sobre sus seres queridos y apoya la justicia al abordar los abusos del pasado. La participación de la UE ha mejorado la coordinación entre organismos gubernamentales y aumentado la conciencia pública, algo esencial para reconstruir la confianza entre ciudadanos e instituciones en Albania.

**Próximo paso** – El embajador Gonzato instó al gobierno albanés a aprobar un plan que organice la búsqueda y recuperación de las personas asesinadas durante el régimen. Se necesitan acciones concretas como esta para asegurar que los esfuerzos continúen y que las personas desaparecidas sean encontradas y honradas.

**Resumen en una frase** – La UE y las instituciones albanesas trabajan juntas para descubrir el destino de las personas desaparecidas del pasado comunista, promoviendo la verdad y la justicia mediante acciones coordinadas.
